DOCNAME: CASE OF BĄCZKOWSKI AND OTHERS v. POLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 11;Violation of Art. 13;Violation of Art. 14
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , a group of individuals and ORG ( of whose executive committee the first applicant is also a member empowered to act on its behalf in the present case ) , wished to hold , within the framework of Equality Days organised by the ORG and planned for CARDINAL DATE , an assembly ( a march ) in GPE with a view to alerting public opinion to the issue of discrimination against minorities – sexual , national , ethnic and religious – and also against women and disabled persons .
CARDINAL . On DATE the organisers held a meeting with the Director of ORG . During this meeting an initial agreement was reached as to the itinerary of the planned march .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON obtained an instruction of ORG on “ requirements which organisers of public assemblies have to comply with under LAW ” should the assembly be regarded as an “ event ” ( impreza ) within the meaning of LAW of that Act .
CARDINAL . On DATE the organisers applied to ORG for permission to organise the march , the itinerary of which would lead from the ORG buildings ( PERSON ) to FAC ( GPE ) in the centre of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Traffic Officer , acting on behalf of the Mayor of GPE , refused permission for the march , relying on the organisers ' failure to submit a “ traffic organisation plan ” ( “ projekt organizacji ruchu ” ) within the meaning of LAW ( a ) of FAC , which they had allegedly been ordered to submit .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants informed the Mayor of GPE about stationary assemblies they intended to hold on DATE in CARDINAL different squares in GPE . CARDINAL of these assemblies were intended to protest about discrimination against various minorities and to support actions of groups and organisations combating discrimination . The other CARDINAL planned assemblies were to protest about discrimination against women .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mayor issued decisions banning the stationary assemblies to be organised by PERSON , PERSON , PERSON Kliszczyński , PERSON , Mr PERSON , and another person , PERSON N. ( who is not an applicant ) , who are active in various nongovernmental organisations acting for the benefit of persons of homosexual orientation . In his decision the Mayor relied on the argument that assemblies held under the provisions of LAW of DATE ( LOC o zgromadzeniach ) had to be organised away from roads used for road traffic . If they were to use roads , more stringent requirements applied . The organisers wished to use cars carrying loudspeakers . They had failed to indicate where and how these cars would park during the assemblies so as not to disturb the traffic , and how the movement of persons and these cars between the assembly sites would be organised .

CARDINAL . NORP Moreover , as a number of requests had been submitted to organise other assemblies on DATE the tenor of which ran counter to the ideas and intentions of the applicants , permission had to be refused in order to avoid any possible violent clashes between participants in the various demonstrations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the municipal authorities , acting on the Mayor 's behalf , allowed the CARDINAL planned assemblies concerning discrimination against women to be held as requested by the applicants .

CARDINAL . On DATE the same authorities permitted CARDINAL other demonstrations to be held on DATE . The themes of these assemblies were as follows : “ For more stringent measures against persons convicted of paedophilia ” , “ Against any legislative work on the law on partnerships ” , “ Against propaganda for partnerships ” , “ Education in NORP values , a guarantee of a moral society ” , “ NORP respecting PERSON 's and nature 's laws are citizens of the first rank ” , “ Against adoption of children by homosexual couples ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE , despite the decision given on DATE , the march took place . It followed the itinerary as planned in the original request of CARDINAL DATE . The march , attended by CARDINAL people , was protected by the police .
CARDINAL . In addition to the march , CARDINAL stationary assemblies were held on DATE under permission granted by the Mayor on DATE ( see paragraphs DATE above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ORG appealed to ORG against the decision of DATE refusing permission for the march . It was argued that the requirement to submit “ a traffic organisation plan ” lacked any legal basis and that the applicants had never been requested to submit such a document prior to the refusal . It was also argued that the decision amounted to an unwarranted restriction of freedom of assembly and that it had been dictated by ideological reasons incompatible with the tenets of democracy .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the contested decision , finding that it was unlawful . ORG observed that under the applicable provisions of administrative procedure the authorities were obliged to ensure that parties to administrative proceedings had an opportunity of effectively participating in them . In the applicant 's case this obligation had not been respected in that the case file contained no evidence that the applicant ORG had been informed of its procedural right to have access to the case file .
The ORG 's decision further read , inter alia :

“ In the written grounds of the decision complained of , the firstinstance authority refers to the fact that no traffic organisation plan is to be found in the case file . Under section CARDINAL ( a ) item CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) an organiser of a demonstration is obliged to develop such a plan in cooperation with the police if he or she is required to do so by the authority . However , in the case file there is no mention that the organisers were obliged to submit such a plan . ( ... ) The document on the procedure for obtaining permission to organise an event which was served on the organisers contained no information on such an obligation either .

Having regard to the fact that the organisers ' request concerned a march to be held on DATE and that the appeal was received by ORG [ together with the case file ] on DATE , the proceedings had already become devoid of purpose by that latter date . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed to the NORP Governor against the Mayor 's refusals of DATE of permission to hold several of the planned assemblies . They argued that the assemblies were to be entirely peaceful and that banning them breached their freedom of assembly guaranteed by LAW . They submitted that the assemblies did not pose any threat to either public order or morals . They contested the argument relied on in the decision that they were required to submit a document on the planned itinerary between the places where the assemblies were to be held , arguing that they only intended to organise stationary assemblies , not any movement of persons between them , and that they should not be held responsible for the organisation or supervision of such movement .
CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP Governor quashed the contested DATE refusals of authorisation to hold the assemblies .

It was first observed that these decisions breached the law in that the parties had been served only with copies of the decisions , not with originals as required by the law on administrative procedure . It was further noted that the Mayor had informed the media of his decisions before they had been served on the applicants , which was manifestly in breach of the principles of administrative procedure .

CARDINAL . It was further observed that LAW was a guarantee of freedom of assembly in respect of both the organisation of and participation in assemblies . The LAW clearly guaranteed freedom of assembly , not a right . It was not for the ORG to create a right to assembly ; its obligation was limited to ensuring that assemblies were held peacefully . Thus the applicable law did not provide for any permit for the holding of an assembly .

CARDINAL . The Governor noted that the requirement to submit a permit to occupy a part of the road , based on the provisions of LAW , lacked any legal basis in the provisions of LAW . The Mayor had assumed that the demonstration would occupy a part of the road , but had failed to take any steps to clarify whether this had really been the organisers ' intention , which he was obliged to do by law .

It was further observed that a decision banning an assembly had to be regarded as a method of last resort because it radically restricted freedom of expression . The principle of proportionality required that any restriction of constitutionally protected freedoms be permitted only in so far as it was dictated by the concrete circumstances of a particular case .

CARDINAL . The Governor noted in this connection that the Mayor 's reliance on the threat of violence between the demonstrations organised by the applicants and the counterdemonstrations planned by other persons and organisations for DATE could not be countenanced . It was tantamount to the administration endorsing the intentions of organisations which clearly and deliberately intended to breach public order , whereas protecting the freedom of expression guaranteed by LAW should be an essential task of the public powers .
CARDINAL . He then discontinued the proceedings as they had become devoid of purpose , the assemblies having taken place on DATE .

CARDINAL . “ PERSON : LAW says that freedom of assembly can be restricted only if a demonstration might entail a danger to life or limb , or a major danger to property . Did the organisers of the march write anything in their application that indicates that there is such a danger ?

Mayor of GPE : NORP I do n't know , I have n't read the application . But I will ban the demonstration regardless of what they have written . I am not for discrimination on the ground of sexual orientation , for example by ruining people 's professional careers . But there will be no public propaganda about homosexuality .
PERSON What you are doing in this case is precisely discrimination : you are making it impossible for people to use their freedom only because of their particular sexual orientation .
MoW : I do not forbid them to demonstrate , if they want to demonstrate as citizens , not as homosexuals .

PERSON Everything seems to suggest DATE like DATE the Governor will quash your prohibition . And if the organisers appeal to the administrative court , they will win , because preventive restrictions on freedom of assembly are unlawful . But the appeal proceedings will last some time and the date for which the march is planned will pass . Is this what you want ?
MoW : We will see whether they win or lose . I will not let myself be persuaded to give my permission for such a demonstration .
PERSON Is it right that the exercise of people 's constitutional rights should depend on the views of the powers that be ?
MoW : In my view , propaganda about homosexuality is not to the same as exercising one 's freedom of assembly . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW reads :
Freedom of peaceful assembly and participation in such assemblies shall be ensured to everyone . Limitations upon such freedoms may be imposed by statute .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW , which entered into force on DATE , provides as follows :

“ In accordance with principles specified by statute , everyone whose constitutional freedoms or rights have been infringed shall have the right to appeal to ORG for a judgment on the conformity with LAW of a statute or other normative act on the basis of which a court or an administrative authority has issued a final decision on his freedoms or rights or on his obligations specified in LAW . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW , insofar as relevant , provides as follows :
“ CARDINAL . Judgments of the Constitutional Court shall be universally binding and final .
CARDINAL . Judgments of ORG , ... shall be published without delay .

CARDINAL . A judgment of the Constitutional Court shall take effect from DATE of its publication ; however , ORG may specify another date for DATE the binding force of a normative act . Such time - limit may not exceed DATE in relation to a statute or DATE in relation to any other normative act . ...

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW , everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly . A gathering of CARDINAL persons , called in order to participate in a public debate or to express an opinion on a given issue , is to be regarded as an assembly within the meaning of the Act .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , freedom of assembly can be restricted only by statute and where it is necessary for the protection of national security or public safety , for the protection of health or morals or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others .

CARDINAL . All decisions concerning the exercise of freedom of assembly must be taken by the local authorities in the municipality where the assembly is to be held . These decisions can be appealed against to the Governor .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , the municipality must be informed by the organisers of the intention to hold a public gathering in the open air for an indeterminate number of persons . Under section CARDINAL such information must be submitted to the municipality not earlier than DATE before the planned date of the demonstration and not DATE before it . The information must include the names and addresses of the organisers , the aim and programme of the demonstration , its place , date and time as well as information about the itinerary if the demonstration is intended to proceed from CARDINAL place to another .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL the municipality shall refuse permission for the demonstration if its purpose is in breach of the LAW itself or of provisions of LAW , or if the demonstration might entail a danger to life or limb , or a major danger to property .

CARDINAL . A first - instance refusal of permission to hold a demonstration must be served on the organisers within DATE of the date on which the relevant request was submitted and not DATE before the planned date of the demonstration . An appeal against such a refusal must be lodged within DATE of the date of its service . NORP The lodging of such an appeal does not have a suspensive effect on the refusal of permission to hold the demonstration .
CARDINAL . A decision given by the appellate authority must be served on the organisers within DATE of the date on which the appeal was submitted .

CARDINAL . Under LAW of LAW of DATE , as amended in DATE , the organisers of sporting events , contests , assemblies and other events which may obstruct road traffic are obliged to obtain permission for the organisation of such assemblies .

CARDINAL . Under LAW read together with LAW DATE ( a ) of the LAW , organisers of such events are obliged to comply with various administrative obligations specified in a list contained in that provision and numbering CARDINAL items , including the obligation to submit a traffic organisation plan to the authorities .
CARDINAL . These provisions were repealed as a result of the judgment of ORG , referred to below .

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE ORG examined a request submitted to it by the ORG to determine whether the requirements imposed on organisers of public events by the provisions of LAW were compatible with the LAW in so far as they impinged on freedom of assembly , or whether they amounted to an excessive limitation of that freedom .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court observed that the essence of the constitutional problem was whether the requirements imposed by section CARDINAL of the Act were compatible with freedom of expression as formulated by the LAW and developed by LAW . It noted that DATE LAW was based on the premise that the exercise of this freedom did not require any authorisations or licences issued by the ORG . As it was a freedom , the ORG was obliged to refrain from hindering its exercise and to ensure that it was enjoyed by various groups despite the fact that their views might not be shared by the majority .
CARDINAL . Accordingly , LAW provided for a system based on nothing more than the registration of the proposed assembly .

The court observed that subsequently , when it enacted LAW , the legislature had incorporated various administrative requirements which were difficult to comply with into the procedure created for the organisation of sporting events , contests and assemblies , thus replacing the registration system by a system based on permission . In so doing , it placed assemblies within the meaning of LAW on a par with events of a commercial character or organised for entertainment purposes . This was incompatible with the special position that freedom of expression occupied in a democratic society and rendered nugatory the special place that assemblies had in the legal system under LAW and LAW . The court also had regard to the fact that the list of requirements imposed by LAW contained CARDINAL sundry administrative obligations . The restrictions on freedom of assembly imposed by that Act were in breach of the requirement of proportionality applicable to all restrictions imposed on the rights guaranteed by LAW .
CARDINAL . The court concluded that CARDINAL of LAW was incompatible with the LAW in so far as it applied to assemblies .
